Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Very-Near-Ground Wireless Channel Modeling: Theory and Practice

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop channel models for radio wave propagation with antennas installed very near ground (H+), at ground level (H0), and/or covered by ice, water, snow, or other materials (H-). The approach is to evaluate the temporal, spatial and spectral statistical characteristics of very near ground antenna channels through simulations, analysis, and measurements conducted in an anechoic chamber and in real environments.

Intellectual Merit: The conducted research includes: 1) development of physics-based propagation models for H+/H0/H- radio channels over a wide range of frequencies to address a variety of applications; 2) exploration of the effect of transmitter and receiver antenna heights, frequency, bandwidth, rough surface materials, and the degree of roughness on the channel model; 3) investigation of near-ground channel dispersion and its impact on direction-of-arrival and time-of-arrival estimation; 4) study of the effect of ground roughness and bandwidth on amplitude, phase, and time-of-arrival statistics in both line-of-sight and non-line-of-sight scenarios as well as spatial correlation and its effect on multi-input-multi-output systems; and 5) design of proper antenna elements and antenna arrays for H+/H0/H- situations.

Broader Impacts: This research should enable optimal design of wireless sensor networks and localization systems for applications such as autonomous collision avoidance, multi-robot collaboration, safety services (firefighting), and under-ground exploration, which would benefit the national economy and security. This project integrates research with education and outreach activities. The theoretical work is demonstrated by practical applications through laboratory activities and measurement processes. Hands-on experiences will be provided for undergraduate students and school teachers. Underrepresented minority students will be recruited into engineering education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Very-Near-Ground Wireless Channel Modeling: Theory and Practice

In this project analytical and experimental aspects of wave propagation when the transmitter and receiver antennas are close to ground was studied extensively. This mode of wireless propagation is encountered at low frequencies (HF- low VHF bands) where the wavelength is large and in the absence of wireless communication infrastructures (base stations and tall towers). The interest in low frequency wireless communication is due to the fact that communication in complex urban environment is dominated by the direct line-of-sight between transmitter and receiver and far less hampered by blockage of buildings in between.  As a result, the adverse effects of communication channels at high frequencies such as attenuation, scattering, multipath, and signal fading can be alleviated. This band of frequency is used by the first responder and military and methods that can enhanced the application and performance of wireless devices in this band is of great interest. Our propagation models are used to estimate the attenuation, coherence bandwidth, and other signal characteristics in different propagation scenarios. Also measurement systems for characterization of wave propagation channels are developed and many measurements that supports our models were carried out. In addition, different miniaturized antennas with relatively high gains that can enable enhanced operation of small handheld radios are developed. Using the developed measurement systems and the antennas different diversity schemes were also examined and was shown that radiation pattern diversity at higher VHF band can improve the data rate. Both undergraduate and graduate students were trained in this project. One Masters student and two Ph.D. students completed their studies on this subject and were partially supported by this NSF grant.
